bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to David L. Edsall, January 9, 1925

div1.p: Kean confirms that Kissinger was a volunteer in the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to David L. Edsall, January 9, 1925
div1.opener:
January 9, 1925.
Dean David L. Edsall,
Harvard University Medical School,
Boston 17, Mass.
My dear Dean Edsall:
div1.p:
I have your letter, written by Miss Richardson,
asking for a statement whether the John R. Kissinger, late
Private, Company D, 157th Indiana Infantry, and Acting
Hospital Steward, Hospital Corps, U.S.A., whose address
was given you by the War Department as Andrews, Huntington
Co., Indiana, is the same man who volunteered to be used
in Major Walter Reed's yellow fever experiments. I am
entirely certain that this is the same man as I knew him
in Cuba and as Disbursing Officer of the Yellow Fever
Commission, I bought him a gòld watch after his recovery
from yellow fever because he at that time refused the
gratuity of $200 which I was authorized to give the vol-
unteers who contracted yellow fever. I have, however,
talked to Capt. Clark of the Finance Department on the
'phone and he informs me that there is no doubt of the
identity as the records show that the Kissinger whose
address was given you is in receipt of an annuity of
$100 a month from the War Department, granted by Congress,
on account of his participation in the yellow fever ex-
periments mentioned above.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired,
Secretary-Treasurer.
